thread.title: A guide to Australian dining
thread.title_full: A guide to Australian dining - Telegraph

author: The Telegraph
title: A guide to Australian dining
text: Seafood specials In New South Wales, keen cooks can learn to prepare dishes, chef-style, at Sydney Seafood School, while Flying Fish restaurant nearby serves a dedicated seafood tasting menu – think blue eye trevalla with white curry and mango yoghurt. Food with a view In Broome, Western Australia, head to the Sunset Bar & Grill overlooking Cable Beach. The food and drink is tasty, the sunset over the Indian Ocean amazing and, from March to October, the “Staircase to the Moon” twinkling on the sea is unforgettable. Sail away Did you know that you can take a gourmet sailing trip over the Great Barrier Reef off the Queensland coast? In between snorkelling in hidden bays, during a week aboard a luxury yacht you’ll dine daily on fresh seafood and enjoy fine wine. In the swing Bonville is an amazing golf course in New South Wales. Native species including swamp wallabies and small kangaroos graze on the light rough and the excellent Flooded Gums Restaurant is possibly the best golf-course eatery in Australia. Grass roots More than 2,500 edible native plants grow on the Australian continent. For tens of thousands of years, they fed the indigenous Australians. Today they are embraced by Australia’s top chefs and can be ordered from the most celebrated menus. A vintage experience At Penfolds Wines in South Australia’s Barossa Valley, try your hand at creating your own wine in the Winemaker’s Laboratory. Here, visitors blend grenache, shiraz and murvedre and it is decanted into personalised bottles to take home. Go wild Learn all about bush medicine and how to live off the land at the award-winning Kooljaman Wilderness Camp in Western Australia. One highlight is catching mud crabs, cooking them over an open fire and dining under a star-filled sky. Picnic heaven Head to Warburton in the Yarra Valley, Victoria, find a shady spot by the river, listen to crickets chirping as you enjoy a picnic of sourdough, cheese and wine. Then take a walk along the railway line built in 1901 to carry local produce to Melbourne. Dishy fish Australia has nearly 600 varieties of fish, both ocean and freshwater, so species such as the barramundi, abalone and lobster feature regularly on Australian menus, cooked in various ways from oriental flavours to good old fish and chips. Harbour lights For the ultimate meal with a view, book a table in the “tower” at Quay, perched between Sydney Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. Not only is it listed in the San Pellegrino World’s Best 50 Restaurants, it offers spetacular 360-degree vistas. Great gourmet getaway Each May, the Port Douglas Carnivale festival in Queensland offers fantastic fare at the Food, Wine and A Taste of Port event. The region’s best restaurants serve dishes under the palm fronds of Rex Smeal Park. • carnivale.com.au Vistas and chips If you’re after the freshest fish and chips right on the beach where the rainforest meets the ocean, the Thornton Beach Kiosk in Cape Tribulation, Queensland, is the place to be. It’s very low key and the views are truly spectacular. • daintreegateway.com.au Have a wild time Floating lunches, table surfing and pop-up events on white-sand beaches... the Kangaroo Island FEASTivale each April is not your typical food and wine event. But then KI, off the South Australia coast, is an island paradise. • tourkangarooisland.com.au Plane sailing Berowra Waters Inn is reached by sea plane from Sydney Harbour. You fly along the coast and across bushland, reaching the restaurant on the Hawkesbury River some 30 minutes later for dinner with a view of the water and the bush • berowrawatersinn.com Paradise awaits The Lizard Island resort sits right on the Great Barrier Reef. It is acclaimed for its 24 deserted beaches, world-class diving and sublime luxury. Enjoy a seven- course beachside degustation dinner under a canopy of stars • lizardisland.com.au To market, to market Head to Sydney Fish Market to watch rock oysters, which only grow in New South Wales, being freshly shucked on site, then head to the waterside to enjoy a platter of your own followed by delicious fish and chips • sydneyfishmarket.com.au A reel good time The Northern Territory is famous for wild barramundi. From March to October, catch your own barramundi, longtail tuna and Spanish mackerel, then cook it up and enjoy a fresh seafood meal at Arnhemland Barra Fishing Lodge • barralodge.com.au A killer experience Fancy a spot of whale watching over dinner? Tuck into seafood at beachside Jonah’s Restaurant and keep an eye out for passing orcas and humpbacks that travel up the New South Wales coast from May to November each year • jonahs.com.au Tasty Tasmania If you like walking and eating, try Tasmania’s Cradle to Coast tasting trail, with itineraries that guide you through the island’s bountiful north-west, from vineyards and farms to food markets and spectacular seafood spots • cradletocoasttastingtrail.com.au Beach glamping Head to Ningaloo Reef in Western Australia for a luxury camping experience. Glamorous tents, complete with beds and en suites, are set on the shoreline and fresh fish dinners are whipped up in a solar-powered kitchen • salsalis.com.au Discover Australia with Etihad Airways, voted the World’s Leading Airline at the World Travel Awards. Etihad offers daily flights from London, Manchester and Edinburgh via Abu Dhabi to Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth from just £609 per person. Terms and conditions apply.
